subject: Re: [junit] Re:Re: Ask some questions about source code of JUnit
msgSnippet: ... In Java, an abstract class can implement an interface even if all the methods are abstract. BaseTestRunner is a base class itself. Its subclasses implement
messageBody:
F. Don wrote:

> Dear J. B. Rainsberger,
>
> >> 2, what is the use of the interface TestRunListener? I can only
> find
> >> the constants in it called, but the methods implemented in
> >> BaseTestRunner is abstract and have no code, they are just left to be
> >> extended?
> >
> >Look at the three test runners for details.
>
> Thank you, I find it.
> But I still don't understand how BaseTestRunner implement the interface
> TestRunListener.
> In class BaseTestRunner, there is an explanation "// TestRunListener
> implementation" before "public abstract void testStarted(String
> testName);" Then how can BaseTestRunner implement it? The signature of
> BaseTestRunner is "public abstract class BaseTestRunner implements
> TestListener", so it implements two interfaces, TestListener and
> TestRunListener?

In Java, an abstract class can implement an interface even if all the
methods are abstract.

BaseTestRunner is a base class itself. Its subclasses implement the
TestRunListener methods. Declaring that BaseTestRunner implements
TestRunListener, but declaring all the methods abstract removes duplication.

> >> 3, the constuctor of TestSuite, TestSuit(Class), can only use
> >> TestCase class (or its subclass) as parameter, then what if I want to
> >> use other extended class?
> >
> >....such as what? How can you create a TestSuite of something else? Why
> >would you?
>
> Maybe someday I want to extend it. ;)
> Just a joke.
> The JUnit framework was designed to allow only TestCase inherited by
> users, wasn't it?
> If someone wants to develop other test tools based on JUnit, should he
> also merely extend from TestCase?

I would think so, yes.
